page.title: 15WOODLAND - PETWORTH RURAL NE
page.content: Gandersgate Lane hedge contains oak, ash, hawthorn, spindleberry, dogrose, bramble, honeysuckle, hazel, maple, crab apple, sallow and dogwood. In Pitsall's Copse there are young plantations of conifer, silver birch and poplar. East of the A272 lie The Cut - so named after being separated from the main wood in the 19th century, and The Mens, (from 'Mennesse', old English for common land). In AD 953 it was pannage, and commoners' grazing rights still remain. Of specie, the woods hold 194 flowers, 43 trees and shrubs, 22 butterflies, a great many birds, rabbits, foxes, a few deer escaped from Petworth Park and some wild mink - a plague to farmers. These 358 acres have been bought by The Sussex Trust for Nature Conservation, which now owns 1,500 acres.
